review.abstract: Syntactic parsers perform poorly in prediction of Argument-Cluster Coordination (ACC). We change the PTB representation of ACC to be more suitable for learning by a statistical PCFG parser, affecting 125 trees in the training set. Training on the modified trees yields a slight improvement in EVALB scores on sections 22 and 23. The main evaluation is on a corpus of 4th grade science exams, in which ACC structures are prevalent. metadata.title: Improved Parsing for Argument-Clusters Coordination

sections.text: Syntactic parsers perform poorly in predicting argument cluster coordination (ACC). We modify the PTB representation of the ACC to make it more suitable for learning by a statistical PCFG parser, which affects 125 trees in the training set. Training on the modified trees results in a slight improvement in EVALB values in Sections 22 and 23. The main evaluation refers to a corpus of 4th grade science tests in which ACC structures predominate. In this corpus, we achieve an impressive improvement in the recovery of ACC structures compared to a parser trained on the original PTB trees.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Many of the faults lie in coordination structures, and structures that involve non-constitutional coordination, such as Argument Cluster Coordination, Right Node-Raising and Gapping (Dowty, 1988), are particularly difficult. Coordination is a common syntactic phenomenon and work has been done to improve the prediction of coordination structures in general cases (Hogan, 2007; Hara et al., 2009; Shimbo and Hara, 2007; Okuma et al., 2009). In this paper, we focus on a specific coordination structure: Argument Cluster Coordination (ACC). sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: We have converted 125 trees with ACC structures in the training sets (sections 2-21) of the PTB to the new representation and trained the parser from Berkeley (Petrov et al., 2006) with its default settings. Since the test and developer sets of the PTB contain only 12 ACC structures that are from and or, we evaluate the parser on Regents, a dataset in which ACC structures predominate (details see below). Since regents do not contain syntactic structures, we focus on the ACC phenomena and evaluate the ability of the parsers to correctly identify the spans of the clusters and the arguments in them. To ensure that the new representation does not affect overall parsing performance, we also evaluate the parer with respect to the traditional development and test sets (sections 22 and 23).As shown in Table 2, the parser results are slightly better when trained with the modified trees.2

sections.heading: 4.1 Regents data-set
sections.text: Regents - a dataset of questions from the Regents 4th grade science exam (the Aristo Challenge), 3 includes 281 sentences with coordination phrases, where 54 of them include argument cluster coordination. We commented on the sentences manually by marking the conjunction spans for the constituent coordination sentences, e.g.: Wendy (ran 19 miles) and (ran 9 miles), as well as the spans of each component of the argumentation cluster coordination, including the inner span of each argument: Mary paid ([$11.08] [for berries]), ([$14.33] [for apples], and ([$9.31] [for peaches]). The bracket in this sentence follows our proposed ACC bracket, and we refer to it as ACCOUR.We also created a version in which the bracket follows the PTB scheme, with the verb included in the span of the first cluster, e.g.: Mary (paid] [11.08] [for berries, [12] for berries, [33] for trees].

We compare the recall value that the parser achieves when trained on the modified trees with the result that the parser succeeds on the original PTB trees, compared to only 47% when trained on the original PTB trees. We will now focus on the specific ACC cases (Table 3). When evaluating the PTB-trained parsers, the recovery of 54.3% of the span was used, compared to only 47% when trained on the original PTB pedals.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: By focusing on the details of a single and relatively rare syntactic construction, the coordination of argumentation clusters, we have been able to significantly improve the analysis results for this construction, while at the same time slightly improving the overall analysis results. More generally, while most current research efforts in natural language processing and syntactic parsing focus on the conception of universal data agnostic techniques, such methods work on common phenomena, often neglecting the very long tail of important constructions. This work shows that there are also benefits to focusing on the details of certain linguistic phenomena and altering the data in such a way that a "data agnostic" system is easier to learn.

Previous NLP research on the Argument Clusters Coordination (Mouret, 2006) as well as the Penn TreeBank annotation guidelines (Marcus et al., 1993; Bies et al., 1995) focused mainly on providing representation schemes capable of expressing the linguistic nuances that may appear in such coordinations.

The resulting representations are relatively complex, and are not easily learnable by current day parsers, including parsers that refine the grammar by learning latent annotations (Petrov et al., 2006), which are thought to be more agnostic to the annotations scheme of the trees.
Parsers that apply latent annotations to the grammar, such as the Berkeley Parser (Petrov et al., 2006) we use in our experiments, can potentially learn some of our proposed refinements on their own.
